    <us-gaap:CommitmentsAndContingenciesDisclosureTextBlock 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 5 &amp;#150; 
Commitments and Contingencies&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Capital Lease 
Obligations&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;In the fourth quarter&#13;of 2013, the Company purchased and upgraded
equipment from non-related third parties, investing approximately $3.5 million. 
In&#13;December 2013, the Company sold the equipment to a related party leasing 
company, Impact Engineering, AS. Simultaneously, the equipment&#13;package was 
leased back to Eco-Stim Energy Solutions Argentina SA (&amp;#147;EcoStim 
Argentina&amp;#148;), a subsidiary of the Company,&#13;as a capital lease for a 
60-month period with payments beginning in February of 2014. The Company agreed 
to prepay one year of&#13;payments in the amount of approximately $1.0 million 
and maintain a balance of no less than six months of prepayments until 
the&#13;final six months of the lease. These prepayments were made prior to 
December 31, 2013. Further rent payments are $81,439 per month&#13;and commenced
on February 1, 2014. The final six months prepaid is shown as other non-current 
assets in the condensed consolidated&#13;balance sheets with a balance of 
$488,633.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr 
style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="width: 
100%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align:

    <us-gaap:DebtDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 6 &amp;#150; Debt&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.25in"&gt;On May 28, 2014&#13;(the &amp;#147;Closing Date&amp;#148;), 
the Company entered into a Convertible Note Facility Agreement (the 
&amp;#147;Note Agreement&amp;#148;)&#13;with ACM Emerging Markets Master Fund I,
L.P. (&amp;#147;ACM&amp;#148;). The proceeds from the Note Agreement have been 
used primarily&#13;for capital expenditures, certain working capital needs and 
approved operating budget expenses.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The Note Agreement&#13;allowed the Company to issue ACM a multiple 
draw secured promissory note with a maximum aggregate principal amount of $22 
million,&#13;convertible into the common stock of the Company (the 
&amp;#147;Common Stock&amp;#148;) at a price of $6.00 per share at the option 
of&#13;ACM. The outstanding debt under the facility is convertible immediately
and accrues interest at 14% per annum with interest payments&#13;due annually in
arrears. The debt can be prepaid in full under certain conditions after the 
first anniversary of the Closing Date&#13;and matures on the date that is four 
years following the Closing Date.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;As of June 30,&#13;2016, the Company has drawn down the full $22 
million available under the Note Agreement, which was primarily used for 
capital&#13;expenditures, certain working capital needs and approved operating 
budget expenses. The balance for accrued interest at June 30,&#13;2016 was 
$286,904.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;On May 28, 2015,&#13;the Company entered into an amendment with ACM. 
ACM and the Company agreed to give ACM the ability to have the $2,485,162 
interest&#13;payment, which was due on May 28, 2015 (the &amp;#147;Deferred 
Interest&amp;#148;), paid in the form of shares of the 
Company&amp;#146;s&#13;common stock upon the consummation of a future equity 
offering, should one occur. On July 15, 2015, the Company issued 
523,192&#13;shares of unregistered common stock at a price of $4.75 per share to
ACM as payment for the Deferred Interest.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;All obligations&#13;under the Note Agreement are secured by liens on 
substantially all of the assets of the Company and have subsidiary 
guarantees&#13;and pledges of the capital stock of the subsidiary guarantors 
subject to certain terms and exceptions. From time to time, management&#13;has 
obtained amendments and waivers to the agreement to accommodate and adapt to the
changing business environment. Management&#13;believes that the Company will be 
in compliance with the amended covenants, but there can be no assurance that the
Company will&#13;achieve such compliance. Failure to comply with these covenants
could result in an event of default which, if not cured or waived,&#13;would 
have a material adverse effect on us. The Company was in compliance with all 
covenants or had obtained any necessary waiver&#13;as of June 30, 
2016.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;On October 10,&#13;2014, the Company entered into an equipment 
purchase agreement for the TPUs equipment and related spare parts for a total 
purchase&#13;price of approximately $6,500,000, of which $4,100,000 was 
financed. The total amount financed, including any accrued interest,&#13;was to 
become due and payable on April 1, 2015. On March 12, 2015, the Company amended 
the agreement to add a blender, two data&#13;vans and a manifold at an increased
cost of $400,000, and amended the due date of the final payment to March 31, 
2016. The amended&#13;agreement provides for monthly installment payments of 
$50,000 beginning in May 2015. The second amended agreement provides 
for&#13;monthly installment payments of $25,000 beginning in April 2016. The 
note accrues interest at a rate of 9% per annum from April&#13;1, 2016 until 
maturity on December 15, 2016. As of June 30, 2016, the Company had a balance of
$1,041,458 and accrued interest&#13;of $38,464.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;On January 1,&#13;2016, the Company financed 
its operational insurance premiums with US Premium Finance for a total of 
$194,611 at an interest rate&#13;of 5.87%. As of June 30, 2016, the Company had 
a balance of $98,493 and accrued interest of $482.&lt;/p&gt;</us-

    <us-gaap:NatureOfOperations contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p 
style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 1 
&amp;#150; Organization and Nature 
of&#13;Business&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Eco-Stim 
Energy Solutions,&#13;Inc. (the &amp;#147;Company,&amp;#148; 
&amp;#147;we&amp;#148; or &amp;#147;us&amp;#148;) is a stage technology-driven 
independent oilfield services&#13;company providing well stimulation, coiled 
tubing and field management services to the upstream oil and gas industry. We 
are focused&#13;on reducing the ecological impact and improving the economic 
performance of the well stimulation process. We have assembled 
technologies&#13;and processes that have the ability to (1) reduce the surface 
footprint, (2) reduce emissions and (3) conserve fuel and water&#13;during the 
stimulation process. The Company will focus on the most active shale resource
basins outside of the United States,&#13;using our technology to differentiate 
our service offerings. Our management team has extensive international industry 
experience.&#13;Our first operation is in Argentina, home to the Vaca Muerta, 
the world&amp;#146;s third-largest shale resource basin as measured&#13;by 
technically recoverable reserves. We also intend to pursue other markets 
including Mexico, Colombia and the United States or&#13;any other location where
we believe we can offer clear advantages and achieve strong returns. The Company
may also explore opportunistic&#13;acquisitions and/or joint ventures with 
established companies in target markets.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:NatureOfOperations>

    <us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Principles of 
Consolidation&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;We 
consolidate all wholly-owned&#13;subsidiaries, controlled joint ventures and 
variable interest entities where the Company has determined it is the primary 
beneficiary.&#13;All material intercompany accounts and transactions have been 
eliminated in consolidation.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ConsolidationPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:UseOfEstimates contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p 
style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Use of
Estimates&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
preparation of financial&#13;statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires 
management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported 
amounts&#13;of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and 
liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and the&#13;reported 
amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Estimates are used 
in, but are not limited to, determining&#13;the following: allowance for 
doubtful accounts, recoverability of long-lived assets and intangibles, useful 
lives used in depreciation&#13;and amortization, income taxes and stock-based 
compensation. The accounting estimates used in the preparation of the 
consolidated&#13;financial statements may change as new events occur, as more 
experience is acquired, as additional information is obtained and&#13;as the 
Company&amp;#146;s operating environment changes.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:UseOfEstimates>
    <us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-
01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Cash and Cash 
Equivalents&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company considers&#13;all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three 
months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents. The Company 
maintains&#13;deposits in several financial institutions, which may at times 
exceed amounts covered by insurance provided by the U.S. Federal&#13;Deposit 
Insurance Corporation (&amp;#147;FDIC&amp;#148;). The Company has not 
experienced any losses related to amounts in excess of&#13;FDIC 
limits.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:CashAndCashEquivalentsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-
06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Revenue 
Recognition&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company&amp;#146;s revenue&#13;is heavily dependent on three major customers. 
All revenue is recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, 
the&#13;price is fixed or determinable, and collection is reasonably assured as 
follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Well 
Stimulation Revenue&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company provides well&#13;stimulation services based on contractual 
arrangements, such as term contracts and pricing agreements, or on a spot market
basis.&#13;Revenue will be recognized and customers will be invoiced upon the 
completion of each job, which can consist of one or more 
stimulation&#13;stages.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Under term
pricing agreement&#13;arrangements, customers commit to targeted utilization 
levels at agreed-upon pricing, but without termination penalties or 
obligations&#13;to pay for services not used by the customer. In addition, the 
agreed-upon pricing is typically subject to periodic 
review.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Spot 
market basis arrangements&#13;are based on an agreed-upon hourly spot market 
rate. The Company also charges fees for setup and mobilization of equipment 
depending&#13;on the job, additional equipment used on the job, if any, and 
materials that are consumed during the well stimulation process.&#13;Generally, 
these fees and other charges vary depending on the equipment and personnel 
required for the job and market conditions&#13;in the region in which the 
services are performed.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company also generates&#13;revenues from chemicals and proppants that are 
consumed while performing well stimulation services.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align:
justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Coiled Tubing Revenue&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The Company began providing&#13;coiled tubing and other well 
stimulation services in early 2015. Jobs for these services are typically short 
term in nature, lasting&#13;anywhere from a few hours to multiple days. Revenue 
is recognized upon completion of each day&amp;#146;s work based upon a 
completed&#13;field ticket. The Company charges the customer for mobilization, 
services performed, personnel on the job, equipment used on the&#13;job, and 
miscellaneous consumables at agreed-upon spot market 
rates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif;
margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Field Management 
Revenue&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company enters into&#13;arrangements to provide field management services. Field
management revenue relates primarily to geophysical predictions and 
production&#13;monitoring, utilizing down-hole diagnostics tools. Revenue is 
recognized and customers are invoiced upon the completion of each&#13;job. The 
service invoices are for a set amount, which includes charges for the 
mobilization of the equipment to the location,&#13;the service performed, the 
personnel on the job, additional equipment used on the job, consumables used 
throughout the course&#13;of the service, and processing and interpretation of 
data acquired via down-hole diagnostic tools.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:RevenueRecognitionPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:FairValueOfFinancialInstrumentsPolicy contextRef="From2016-01-
01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair Value of Financial 
Instruments&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company&amp;#146;s financial&#13;instruments consist of cash and cash 
equivalents, accounts receivable, other assets, accounts payable, accrued 
expenses, capital&#13;lease obligations and notes payable. The recorded values 
of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, other assets, 
accounts&#13;payable, and accrued expenses approximate their fair values based 
on their short-term nature. The carrying value of capital lease&#13;obligations 
and notes payable approximate their fair value, and the interest rates 
approximate market rates.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:FairValueOfFinancialInstrumentsPolicy>
    <us-gaap:ForeignCurrencyTransactionsAndTranslationsPolicyTextBlock 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Functional and 
Presentation Currency&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent:
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Items 
included in the&#13;financial statements of each of the Company&amp;#146;s 
entities are measured using the currency of the primary economic 
environment&#13;in which the entity operates (the &amp;#147;functional 
currency&amp;#148;). The functional currency for the Norwegian and 
Argentine&#13;subsidiaries is the U.S. Dollar. The consolidated financial 
statements are presented in U.S. Dollars, which is the 
Company&amp;#146;s&#13;presentation currency.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:ForeignCurrencyTransactionsAndTranslationsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:MarketableSecuritiesPolicy contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Marketable 
Securities&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;Investments in&#13;marketable securities are classified as trading, 
available-for-sale or held-to-maturity. Our marketable equity investments 
are&#13;classified as trading and their cost basis is determined by the specific
identification method. Realized and unrealized gains and&#13;losses on trading 
securities are included in net income.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;During the six&#13;months ended June 30, 2015, the Company purchased 
and sold Argentine bonds to capitalize its subsidiary in Argentina. This 
resulted&#13;in a gain on the sale of trading securities of $872,920 for the six
months ended June 30, 2015. This increase was primarily due&#13;to the Company 
taking advantage of the favorable spread in exchange rates between the U.S. 
Dollar and Argentine Peso.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:MarketableSecuritiesPolicy>
    <us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-
06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Net Loss per Common 
Share&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;For
the six months&#13;ended June 30, 2016 and 2015, the weighted average shares 
outstanding excluded certain stock options and potential shares 
from&#13;convertible debt of 4,412,132 and 4,117,964, respectively, from the 
calculation of diluted earnings per share because these shares&#13;would be 
anti-dilutive. Anti-dilutive warrants of 100,000 for each of the six months 
ended June 30, 2016 and 2015 were also excluded&#13;from the 
calculation.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:EarningsPerSharePolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:TradeAndOtherAccountsReceivablePolicy contextRef="From2016-01-
01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Accounts 
Receivable&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Accounts 
receivable are&#13;stated at amounts management expects to collect from 
outstanding balances both billed and unbilled (unbilled accounts 
receivable&#13;represent amounts recognized as revenue for which invoices have 
not yet been sent to clients). Management provides for 
probable&#13;uncollectible amounts through a charge to earnings and a credit to 
a valuation allowance based on its assessment of the current&#13;status of 
individual accounts. To date, the Company has not recognized any losses due to 
uncollectible accounts. Balances still&#13;outstanding after management has used
reasonable collection efforts are written off through a charge to the valuation 
allowance&#13;and a credit to accounts receivable. The Company evaluated all 
accounts receivable and determined that no reserve for doubtful&#13;accounts was
necessary at June 30, 2016 and 2015.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:TradeAndOtherAccountsReceivablePolicy>
    <ESES:PrepaidPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p 
style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Prepaids&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&l
t;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-
align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Prepaid expenses&#13;are primarily comprised of
Argentinian value added tax and prepaid insurance. The prepaid value added tax 
will be reduced as the&#13;Company continues to invoice customers in 
Argentina.&lt;/p&gt;</ESES:PrepaidPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:InventoryPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Inventory&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&
lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-
align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Inventories are&#13;stated at the lower of cost
or market (net realizable value) using the average method and appropriate 
consideration is given to&#13;deterioration, obsolescence and other factors in 
evaluating net realizable value.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:InventoryPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-
01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Property, Plant and 
Equipment&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;Property, Plant&#13;and Equipment (&amp;#147;PPE&amp;#148;) is stated
at historical cost less depreciation. Historical cost includes expenditures that
are&#13;directly attributable to the acquisition of the 
items.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;Depreciation is&#13;computed using the straight-line method over the 
estimated useful lives of the assets for financial reporting purposes. 
Expenditures&#13;for major renewals and betterments that extend the useful lives
are capitalized. Expenditures for normal maintenance and repairs&#13;are 
expensed as incurred. The cost of assets sold or abandoned and the related 
accumulated depreciation are eliminated from the&#13;accounts and any gains or 
losses are reflected in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations 
for the respective period.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The
estimated useful&#13;lives of our major classes of PPE are as 
follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="font: 11pt Calibri, Helvetica, Sans-Serif; width: 100%; 
border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;

years (or the life of the lease)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td

    <us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionLeases contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Leases&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;
p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align:
justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.25in"&gt;The Company leases&#13;certain equipment under lease 
agreements. The Company evaluates each lease to determine its appropriate 
classification as an operating&#13;or capital lease for financial reporting 
purposes. Any lease that does not meet the criteria for a capital lease is 
accounted&#13;for as an operating lease. The assets and liabilities under 
capital leases are recorded at the lower of the present value of the&#13;minimum
lease payments or the fair market value of the related assets. Assets under 
capital leases are amortized using the straight-line&#13;method over the lease 
term. Amortization of assets under capital leases is included in depreciation 
expense.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:RevenueRecognitionLeases>
    <us-gaap:ShareBasedCompensationOptionAndIncentivePlansPolicy 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Stock-Based 
Compensation&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The Company accounts&#13;for its stock options, warrants, and 
restricted stock grants under the fair value recognition provisions of the 
Financial Accounting&#13;Standards Board (&amp;#147;FASB&amp;#148;) Accounting 
Standards Codification (&amp;#147;ASC&amp;#148;) Topic 718. The Company 
currently uses&#13;the straight-line amortization method for recognizing stock 
option and restricted stock compensation costs. The measurement 
and&#13;recognition of compensation expense for all share-based payment awards 
made to our employees, directors or outside service providers&#13;are based on 
the estimated fair value of the awards on the grant dates. The grant date fair 
value is estimated using either an&#13;option-pricing model which is consistent 
with the terms of the award or a market observed price, if such a price exists. 
Such&#13;cost is recognized over the period during which an employee, director 
or outside service provider is required to provide service&#13;in exchange for 
the award, i.e., &amp;#147;the requisite service period&amp;#148; (which is 
usually the vesting period). The Company&#13;also estimates the number of 
instruments that will ultimately be earned, rather than accounting for 
forfeitures as they occur.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:ShareBasedCompensationOptionAndIncentivePlansPolicy>
<us-gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsPolicyTextBlock 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Impairment of
Long-Lived Assets&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The Company reviews&#13;its long-lived assets for impairment when 
changes in circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not 
be recoverable.&#13;ASC Topic 360 requires the Company to review long-lived 
assets for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances 
indicate&#13;the carrying amount of an asset or group of assets may not be 
recoverable. The impairment review includes a comparison of future&#13;cash 
flows expected to be generated by the asset or group of assets with their 
associated carrying value. If the carrying value&#13;of the asset or group of 
assets exceeds expected cash flows (undiscounted and without interest charges), 
an impairment loss is&#13;recognized to the extent that the carrying value 
exceeds the fair value. If estimated future cash flows are not achieved 
with&#13;respect to long-lived assets, additional write-downs may be required. 
The Company evaluated its long-lived assets for impairment&#13;at June 30, 2016 
and has determined no impairment is necessary.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:ImpairmentOrDisposalOfLongLivedAssetsPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Major Customers and Concentration&#13;of Credit 
Risk&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The majority of&#13;the Company&amp;#146;s business is conducted with
major and independent oil and gas companies in Argentina. The Company 
evaluates&#13;the financial strength of its customers and provides allowances 
for probable credit losses when deemed necessary. The Company derives&#13;a 
large amount of revenue from a small number of major and independent oil and gas
companies.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;We derive a significant&#13;portion of our revenue from a limited 
number of major clients. For the six months ended June 30, 2016, three major 
customers accounted&#13;for approximately 91.2% of our services revenue. Our 
accounts receivable, at June 30, 2016 were concentrated, with major 
customers&#13;representing 92.2%. Pluspetrol, YPF and Madalena represent our 
largest customers.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ConcentrationRiskCreditRisk>
    <us-gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-
30">&lt;p style="margin: 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Income 
Taxes&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Deferred 
income taxes&#13;are determined using the asset and liability method in 
accordance with ASC Topic 740. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are 
recognized&#13;for the future tax consequences attributable to differences 
between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets&#13;and 
liabilities and their respective tax bases. Deferred income taxes are measured 
using enacted tax rates expected to apply to&#13;taxable income in years in 
which such temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The 
effect of a change in&#13;tax rates on deferred income taxes is recognized in 
the consolidated statement of operations of the period that includes the 
enactment&#13;date. In addition, a valuation allowance is established to reduce
any deferred tax asset for which it is determined that it is&#13;more likely 
than not that some portion of the deferred tax asset will not be 
realized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The
Company is subject&#13;to U.S. federal and foreign income taxes along with state
income taxes in Texas. When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain&#13;that
some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing 
authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty&#13;about the merits of the
position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
The benefit of a tax&#13;position is recognized in the financial statements in 
the period during which, based on all available evidence, management 
believes&#13;it is more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon
examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation&#13;processes, if
any. Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions. Tax 
positions that meet the more-likely-than-not&#13;recognition threshold are 
measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50% likely of 
being realized upon settlement&#13;with the applicable taxing authority. The 
portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the 
amount&#13;measured as described above is reflected as a liability for 
unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying consolidated balance&#13;sheets 
along with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to the 
taxing authorities upon examination.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:IncomeTaxPolicyTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Recent Accounting 
Pronouncements&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;In 
April 2015, the FASB&#13;issued ASU 2015-03, &amp;#147;Simplifying the 
Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs,&amp;#148; which amends the current 
presentation of&#13;debt issuance costs in the financial statements. ASU 2015-03
requires that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability&#13;be 
presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of
that debt liability, consistent with debt&#13;discounts, instead of as an asset.
The amendments are to be applied retrospectively and are effective for public 
business entities&#13;for fiscal years, and for interim periods within those 
fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2015, but early adoption 
is&#13;permitted. We adopted ASU 2015-03 during the quarter ended March 31, 2016
resulting in reclassification of short-term debt issuance&#13;cost of $185,362 
and $185,362 as of June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015 respectively; and long-
term debt issuance cost of $169,916&#13;and $262,597 as of June 30, 2016 and 
December 31, 2015 respectively.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:NewAccountingPronouncementsPolicyPolicyTextBlock>

    <us-gaap:BasisOfPresentationAndSignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin:
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Note 2 &amp;#150; Basis of 
Presentation and&#13;Significant Accounting 
Policies&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
accompanying unaudited&#13;condensed consolidated financial statements have been
prepared in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in 
the&#13;United States (&amp;#147;U.S. GAAP&amp;#148;) for interim financial 
information. Accordingly, they do not include all of the information&#13;and 
footnotes required by U.S. GAAP for complete financial statements. The December 
31, 2015 consolidated balance sheet was derived&#13;from audited financial 
statements, but does not include all the disclosures required by U.S. GAAP. 
However, the Company believes&#13;that the disclosures are adequate to make the 
information presented not misleading. In the Company&amp;#146;s opinion, all the
adjustments&#13;(consisting of normal recurring adjustments) considered 
necessary for fair presentation have been included. The results of 
operations&#13;for the six month period ended June 30, 2016 are not necessarily 
indicative of the results that may be achieved for the full fiscal&#13;year or 
for any future period. The unaudited condensed consolidated financial statements
included herein should be read in conjunction&#13;with the consolidated 
financial statements and notes thereto for the year ended December 31, 2015, a 
copy of which was filed with&#13;the Company&amp;#146;s Annual Report on Form 
10-K for the year ended December 31, 2015.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent:
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Principles of
Consolidation&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;We 
consolidate all wholly-owned&#13;subsidiaries, controlled joint ventures and 
variable interest entities where the Company has determined it is the primary 
beneficiary.&#13;All material intercompany accounts and transactions have been 
eliminated in consolidation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Use of 
Estimates&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
preparation of financial&#13;statements in conformity with U.S. GAAP requires 
management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported 
amounts&#13;of assets and liabilities and disclosure of contingent assets and 
liabilities at the date of the financial statements, and the&#13;reported 
amounts of revenue and expenses during the reporting period. Estimates are used 
in, but are not limited to, determining&#13;the following: allowance for 
doubtful accounts, recoverability of long-lived assets and intangibles, useful 
lives used in depreciation&#13;and amortization, income taxes and stock-based 
compensation. The accounting estimates used in the preparation of the 
consolidated&#13;financial statements may change as new events occur, as more 
experience is acquired, as additional information is obtained and&#13;as the 
Company&amp;#146;s operating environment changes.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&l
t;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Cash and Cash 
Equivalents&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The
Company considers&#13;all highly liquid investments with a maturity of three 
months or less when purchased to be cash equivalents. The Company 
maintains&#13;deposits in several financial institutions, which may at times 
exceed amounts covered by insurance provided by the U.S. Federal&#13;Deposit 
Insurance Corporation (&amp;#147;FDIC&amp;#148;). The Company has not 
experienced any losses related to amounts in excess of&#13;FDIC 
limits.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Revenue 
Recognition&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company&amp;#146;s revenue&#13;is heavily dependent on three major customers. 
All revenue is recognized when persuasive evidence of an arrangement exists, 
the&#13;price is fixed or determinable, and collection is reasonably assured as 
follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Well 
Stimulation Revenue&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company provides well&#13;stimulation services based on contractual 
arrangements, such as term contracts and pricing agreements, or on a spot market
basis.&#13;Revenue will be recognized and customers will be invoiced upon the 
completion of each job, which can consist of one or more 
stimulation&#13;stages.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Under term
pricing agreement&#13;arrangements, customers commit to targeted utilization 
levels at agreed-upon pricing, but without termination penalties or 
obligations&#13;to pay for services not used by the customer. In addition, the 
agreed-upon pricing is typically subject to periodic 
review.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Spot 
market basis arrangements&#13;are based on an agreed-upon hourly spot market 
rate. The Company also charges fees for setup and mobilization of equipment 
depending&#13;on the job, additional equipment used on the job, if any, and 
materials that are consumed during the well stimulation process.&#13;Generally, 
these fees and other charges vary depending on the equipment and personnel 
required for the job and market conditions&#13;in the region in which the 
services are performed.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company also generates&#13;revenues from chemicals and proppants that are 
consumed while performing well stimulation services.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Coiled Tubing Revenue&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The Company began providing&#13;coiled tubing and other well 
stimulation services in early 2015. Jobs for these services are typically short 
term in nature, lasting&#13;anywhere from a few hours to multiple days. Revenue 
is recognized upon completion of each day&amp;#146;s work based upon a
completed&#13;field ticket. The Company charges the customer for mobilization, 
services performed, personnel on the job, equipment used on the&#13;job, and 
miscellaneous consumables at agreed-upon spot market 
rates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
 Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;i&gt;Field Management 
Revenue&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company enters into&#13;arrangements to provide field management services. Field
management revenue relates primarily to geophysical predictions and 
production&#13;monitoring, utilizing down-hole diagnostics tools. Revenue is 
recognized and customers are invoiced upon the completion of each&#13;job. The 
service invoices are for a set amount, which includes charges for the 
mobilization of the equipment to the location, the&#13;service performed, the 
personnel on the job, additional equipment used on the job, consumables used 
throughout the course of the&#13;service, and processing and interpretation of 
data acquired via down-hole diagnostic tools.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair Value of Financial 
Instruments&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The 
Company&amp;#146;s financial&#13;instruments consist of cash and cash 
equivalents, accounts receivable, other assets, accounts payable, accrued 
expenses, capital&#13;lease obligations and notes payable. The recorded values 
of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, other assets, 
accounts&#13;payable, and accrued expenses approximate their fair values based 
on their short-term nature. The carrying value of capital lease&#13;obligations 
and notes payable approximate their fair value, and the interest rates 
approximate market rates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&l
t;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Functional and Presentation 
Currency&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Items 
included in the&#13;financial statements of each of the Company&amp;#146;s 
entities are measured using the currency of the primary economic 
environment&#13;in which the entity operates (the &amp;#147;functional 
currency&amp;#148;). The functional currency for the Norwegian and Argentine 
subsidiaries&#13;is the U.S. Dollar. The consolidated financial statements are 
presented in U.S. Dollars, which is the Company&amp;#146;s 
presentation&#13;currency.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Marketable 
Securities&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;Investments in&#13;marketable securities are classified as trading, 
available-for-sale or held-to-maturity. Our marketable equity investments 
are&#13;classified as trading and their cost basis is determined by the specific
identification method. Realized and unrealized gains and&#13;losses on trading 
securities are included in net income.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;During the six&#13;months ended June 30, 2015, the Company purchased 
and sold Argentine bonds to capitalize its subsidiary in Argentina. This 
resulted&#13;in a gain on the sale of trading securities of $872,920 for the six
months ended June 30, 2015. This increase was primarily due&#13;to the Company 
taking advantage of the favorable spread in exchange rates between the U.S. 
Dollar and Argentine Peso.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&l
t;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-
align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Net Loss per Common 
Share&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;For
the six months&#13;ended June 30, 2016 and 2015, the weighted average shares 
outstanding excluded certain stock options and potential shares 
from&#13;convertible debt of 4,412,132 and 4,117,964, respectively, from the 
calculation of diluted earnings per share because these shares&#13;would be 
anti-dilutive. Anti-dilutive warrants of 100,000 for each of the six months 
ended June 30, 2016 and 2015 were also excluded&#13;from the 
calculation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Reclassifications&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#1
3;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; 
text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Certain prior year&#13;amounts have been 
reclassified to conform to the 2015 presentation.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Accounts 
Receivable&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Accounts 
receivable are&#13;stated at amounts management expects to collect from 
outstanding balances both billed and unbilled (unbilled accounts 
receivable&#13;represent amounts recognized as revenue for which invoices have 
not yet been sent to clients). Management provides for 
probable&#13;uncollectible amounts through a charge to earnings and a credit to 
a valuation allowance based on its assessment of the current&#13;status of 
individual accounts. To date, the Company has not recognized any losses due to 
uncollectible accounts. Balances still&#13;outstanding after management has used
reasonable collection efforts are written off through a charge to the valuation 
allowance&#13;and a credit to accounts receivable. The Company evaluated all 
accounts receivable and determined that no reserve for doubtful&#13;accounts was
necessary at June 30, 2016 and 2015.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Prepaids&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&l
t;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-
align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Prepaid expenses&#13;are primarily comprised of
Argentinian value added tax and prepaid insurance. The prepaid value added tax 
will be reduced as the&#13;Company continues to invoice customers in 
Argentina.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Inventory&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&
lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-
align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Inventories are&#13;stated at the lower of cost
or market (net realizable value) using the average method and appropriate 
consideration is given to&#13;deterioration, obsolescence and other factors in 
evaluating net realizable
 value.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Property, Plant and 
Equipment&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;Property, Plant&#13;and Equipment (&amp;#147;PPE&amp;#148;) is stated
at historical cost less depreciation. Historical cost includes expenditures that
are&#13;directly attributable to the acquisition of the 
items.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times,
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;Depreciation is&#13;computed using the straight-line method over the 
estimated useful lives of the assets for financial reporting purposes. 
Expenditures&#13;for major renewals and betterments that extend the useful lives
are capitalized. Expenditures for normal maintenance and repairs&#13;are 
expensed as incurred. The cost of assets sold or abandoned and the related 
accumulated depreciation are eliminated from the&#13;accounts and any gains or 
losses are reflected in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations 
for the respective period.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The
estimated useful&#13;lives of our major classes of PPE are as 
follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" 
cellpadding="0" style="font: 11pt Calibri, Helvetica, Sans-Serif; width: 100%; 
border-collapse: collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;  
&lt;td colspan="4"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    
&lt;td style="width: 40%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; line-height: 
115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Major Classes of PPE&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;  
&lt;td style="width: 1%; line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    
&lt;td style="width: 39%; border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; line-height: 
115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Estimated Useful Lives&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;
&lt;td style="padding-bottom: 10pt; width: 20%; line-height: 
115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"&gt;Machinery and equipment&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="line-
height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;2-
7 years&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 10pt; 
line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    
&lt;td style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif"&gt;Vehicles&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="line-
height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="line-height: 
115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;5
years&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 10pt; line-
height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"&gt;Leasehold improvements&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="line-
height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;5 
years (or the life of the lease)&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="padding-bottom: 10pt; line-height: 
115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"&gt;Furniture and office equipment&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="line-
height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;3-
5 years&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="padding-bottom: 10pt; 
line-height: 
115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Leases&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;
p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align:
justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font:
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.25in"&gt;The Company leases&#13;certain equipment under lease 
agreements. The Company evaluates each lease to determine its appropriate 
classification as an operating&#13;or capital lease for financial reporting 
purposes. Any lease that does not meet the criteria for a capital lease is 
accounted for&#13;as an operating lease. The assets and liabilities under 
capital leases are recorded at the lower of the present value of the 
minimum&#13;lease payments or the fair market value of the related assets. 
Assets under capital leases are amortized using the straight-line&#13;method 
over the lease term. Amortization of assets under capital leases is included in 
depreciation expense.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Stock-
Based Compensation&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-
indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The Company accounts&#13;for its stock options, warrants, and 
restricted stock grants under the fair value recognition provisions of the 
Financial Accounting&#13;Standards Board (&amp;#147;FASB&amp;#148;) Accounting 
Standards Codification (&amp;#147;ASC&amp;#148;) Topic 718. The Company 
currently uses&#13;the straight-line amortization method for recognizing stock 
option and restricted stock compensation costs. The measurement 
and&#13;recognition of compensation expense for all share-based payment awards 
made to our employees, directors or outside service providers&#13;are based on 
the estimated fair value of the awards on the grant dates. The grant date fair 
value is estimated using either an&#13;option-pricing model which is consistent 
with the terms of the award or a market observed price, if such a price exists. 
Such cost&#13;is recognized over the period during which an employee, director 
or outside service provider is required to provide service in&#13;exchange for 
the award, i.e., &amp;#147;the requisite service period&amp;#148; (which is 
usually the vesting period). The Company also&#13;estimates the number of 
instruments that will ultimately be earned, rather than accounting for 
forfeitures as they occur.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived 
Assets&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The
Company reviews&#13;its long-lived assets for impairment when changes in 
circumstances indicate that the carrying amount of an asset may not be 
recoverable.&#13;ASC Topic 360 requires the Company to review long-lived assets 
for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate&#13;the 
carrying amount of an asset or group of assets may not be recoverable. The 
impairment review includes a comparison of future&#13;cash flows expected to be 
generated by the asset or group of assets with their associated carrying value. 
If the carrying value&#13;of the asset or group of assets exceeds expected cash 
flows (undiscounted and without interest charges), an impairment loss 
is&#13;recognized to the extent that the carrying value exceeds the fair value. 
If estimated future cash flows are not achieved with respect&#13;to long-lived 
assets, additional write-downs may be required. The Company evaluated its long-
lived assets for impairment at June&#13;30, 2016 and has determined no 
impairment is necessary.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p
 style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: 
justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Major Customers and Concentration&#13;of Credit 
Risk&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;The majority of&#13;the Company&amp;#146;s business is conducted with
major and independent oil and gas companies in Argentina. The Company 
evaluates&#13;the financial strength of its customers and provides allowances 
for probable credit losses when deemed necessary. The Company derives&#13;a 
large amount of revenue from a small number of major and independent oil and gas
companies.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New Roman, 
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times 
New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;We derive a significant&#13;portion of our revenue from a limited 
number of major clients. For the six months ended June 30, 2016, three major 
customers accounted&#13;for approximately 91.2% of our services revenue. Our 
accounts receivable, at June 30, 2016 were concentrated, with major 
customers&#13;representing 92.2%. Pluspetrol, YPF and Madalena represent our 
largest customers.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt/normal Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Income
Taxes&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman,
Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;Deferred 
income taxes&#13;are determined using the asset and liability method in 
accordance with ASC Topic 740. Deferred tax assets and liabilities are 
recognized&#13;for the future tax consequences attributable to differences 
between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets&#13;and 
liabilities and their respective tax bases. Deferred income taxes are measured 
using enacted tax rates expected to apply to&#13;taxable income in years in 
which such temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled. The 
effect of a change in&#13;tax rates on deferred income taxes is recognized in 
the consolidated statement of operations of the period that includes the 
enactment&#13;date. In addition, a valuation allowance is established to reduce 
any deferred tax asset for which it is determined that it is&#13;more likely 
than not that some portion of the deferred tax asset will not be 
realized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;The
Company is subject&#13;to U.S. federal and foreign income taxes along with state
income taxes in Texas. When tax returns are filed, it is highly certain&#13;that
some positions taken would be sustained upon examination by the taxing
authorities, while others are subject to uncertainty&#13;about the merits of the
position taken or the amount of the position that would be ultimately sustained.
The benefit of a tax position&#13;is recognized in the financial statements in 
the period during which, based on all available evidence, management believes it
is&#13;more likely than not that the position will be sustained upon 
examination, including the resolution of appeals or litigation processes,&#13;if
any. Tax positions taken are not offset or aggregated with other positions. Tax 
positions that meet the more-likely-than-not&#13;recognition threshold are 
measured as the largest amount of tax benefit that is more than 50% likely of 
being realized upon settlement&#13;with the applicable taxing authority. The 
portion of the benefits associated with tax positions taken that exceeds the 
amount measured&#13;as described above is reflected as a liability for 
unrecognized tax benefits in the accompanying consolidated balance sheets 
along&#13;with any associated interest and penalties that would be payable to 
the taxing authorities upon examination.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 
10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent:
0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Times New 
Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Recent
Accounting Pronouncements&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify;
text-indent: 0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt 
Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify; text-indent: 
0.25in"&gt;In April 2015, the FASB&#13;issued ASU 2015-03, &amp;#147;Simplifying
the Presentation of Debt Issuance Costs,&amp;#148; which amends the current 
presentation of&#13;debt issuance costs in the financial statements. ASU 2015-03
requires that debt issuance costs related to a recognized debt liability&#13;be 
presented in the balance sheet as a direct deduction from the carrying amount of
that debt liability, consistent with debt&#13;discounts, instead of as an asset.
The amendments are to be applied retrospectively and are effective for public 
business entities&#13;for fiscal years, and for interim periods within those 
fiscal years, beginning after December 15, 2015, but early adoption 
is&#13;permitted. We adopted ASU 2015-03 during the quarter ended March 31, 2016
resulting in reclassification of short-term debt issuance&#13;cost of $185,362 
and $185,362 as of June 30, 2016 and December 31, 2015 respectively; and long-
term debt issuance cost of $169,916&#13;and $262,597 as of June 30, 2016 and 
December 31, 2015 respectively.&lt;/p&gt;</us-
gaap:BasisOfPresentationAndSignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ScheduleOfAccountsNotesLoansAndFinancingReceivableTextBlock 
contextRef="From2016-01-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="margin: 
0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellspacing="0" cellpadding="0" 
style="font: 11pt Calibri, Helvetica, Sans-Serif; width: 100%; border-collapse: 
collapse"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td 
style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="line-
height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" style="border-
bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center; line-height: 115%"&gt;&lt;font 
style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&lt;b&gt;June 30, 
2016&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center;
line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: 
center; line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td colspan="2" 
style="border-bottom: black 1.5pt solid; text-align: center; line-height: 
115%"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 10pt Times New Roman, Times, 
Serif"&gt;&lt;b&gt;December 31, 2015&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    
&lt;td style="line-height: 115%"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr
